content.description: Dependent Personality Disorder (DPD) is characterized by a pervasive and excessive need to be taken care of, leading to submissive and clinging behavior and fears of separation. This pattern begins by early adulthood and is present in a variety of contexts.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A pervasive and excessive need to be taken care of that leads to submissive and clinging behavior and fears of separation, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by ≥5 of: (1) Difficulty making everyday decisions without excessive advice/reassurance; (2) Needs others to assume responsibility for most major life areas; (3) Difficulty expressing disagreement due to fear of loss of support; (4) Difficulty initiating projects on their own; (5) Goes to excessive lengths to obtain nurturance/support; (6) Feels uncomfortable/helpless when alone; (7) Urgently seeks new relationship as a source of care when one ends; (8) Unrealistically preoccupied with fears of being left to care for self.
content.prevalence: Estimated ~0.5% in the general population; more common in clinical settings and among females in some studies.
content.age_of_onset: Early adulthood, though dependent traits may be evident in adolescence.
content.prognosis: Course is chronic without treatment, but symptoms may improve with psychotherapy. Risk of depression, anxiety, and abuse in relationships is elevated.

circuitry: Limited direct neuroimaging evidence; possible overlap with anxiety-related circuitry involving the amygdala and prefrontal cortex.
neurochemistry: No established neurotransmitter abnormalities specific to DPD; anxiety-related neurochemical patterns may be relevant.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Heritability is modest; often associated with overprotective or authoritarian parenting, chronic illness in childhood, or insecure attachment.

history_psychosocial: Patterns of reliance on others for decision-making and emotional support.
History of relationships, attachment style, and early caregiving experiences.
medical_assessment: Screen for comorbid anxiety and depressive disorders.
standardized_measures: Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Personality Disorders (SCID-5-PD).
risk_stratification: Degree of functional impairment, vulnerability to exploitation, comorbid psychiatric conditions.
evaluation.team_and_process: Multidisciplinary approach including psychotherapy and support for autonomy-building.

severity_levels.mild: Occasional excessive reliance on others but able to function independently in some areas.
severity_levels.moderate: Frequent difficulty functioning independently; marked distress when alone.
severity_levels.severe: Almost complete dependence on others for emotional and practical decisions; high vulnerability to exploitation.

biological: History of chronic illness in childhood
environmental: Lack of opportunities to develop autonomy

impact_on_life.school_work: Difficulty making independent decisions, relying on peers or supervisors excessively.
impact_on_life.social: Tendency to stay in relationships even when unhealthy to avoid being alone.
impact_on_life.medical: Increased risk of neglecting self-care without external prompting.
impact_on_life.emotional: Persistent anxiety about abandonment and feelings of inadequacy.

psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) focused on building autonomy and decision-making skills.
Schema Therapy targeting maladaptive beliefs about self-reliance.
medications: No specific pharmacologic treatment; SSRIs/SNRIs may be used for comorbid depression or anxiety.
care_coordination: Support networks to encourage healthy independence.

treatment_goals: Reduce reliance on others for emotional regulation.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Misinterpreting dependence as cultural norm without assessing impairment.
Overlooking symptoms in the context of chronic medical illness.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling close relational bonds as pathological dependence.
Confusing situational dependence after loss with chronic personality pattern.
warning_signs: Inability to function after loss of a relationship
Rapid replacement of relationships to avoid being alone
self_help_strategies: Set small, achievable goals for independent tasks.
Practice making decisions without seeking reassurance.
Engage in activities that foster self-reliance.

adolescence: Reluctance to separate from parents; overreliance on close friends for decisions.
adulthood: Persistent need for care from partners or friends; difficulty functioning alone.

real_life_examples: A 25-year-old who cannot choose a career path without parental input starts CBT and gradually gains confidence in independent choices.
A 40-year-old who remains in an unhealthy relationship to avoid being alone works on assertiveness and autonomy skills in therapy.
content.when_to_seek_help: When fear of abandonment or inability to function independently causes distress or vulnerability to exploitation.
